title: Business wrestles with an identity crisis
text:
Business walk the line

BCA CEO Jennifer Westacott is trying to walk the line between her members and Canberra, after Ben Morton, Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, warned that business had been “seduced by the noisy elites, who try to bend business to their narrow viewpoints”.

Westacott argues that rather than some faceless, unemotional conglomerate, business is the “11 million people who work in it”.

Dexus CEO Darren Steinberg believes the property industry avoids social issues that might offend some customers. Peter Braig

“It’s the mum and dad shareholders who own it, it’s the customers, it’s the suppliers and contractors, the communities that people operate in, and many times people feel strongly about companies taking a stand,” she says. “But we’ve got to get the balance right.”

Business leaders “should not be torn” between shareholders or the community because “the two are not in conflict”, Westacott says.

“Companies represent their shareholders because they have taken the risk,” she says. “But to create value for shareholders in the long term, you’ve got to look after your employees, customers and suppliers.”

Politicians and the public are right to question whether “companies are lecturing”, but in most cases, she says, they are “doing what they say”.

Who are CEOs to change the rules

A similar point was made at The Australian Financial Review Property Summit in September, where Dexus CEO Darren Steinberg said that while climate change was a top priority for the property industry, it did not delve into other social issues that might offend some customers.

JLL Australia CEO Stephen Conroy agreed that “CEOs should be careful because they’ll be seen by their staff to be bullying them into a personal view”.

But Mirvac CEO Susan Lloyd-Hurwitz said property companies played a huge role in creating the spaces where people live and work. “The impact we have on people’s lives is enormous, and that’s a social responsibility we have,” she says.

The debate has been bubbling along for years but has gained momentum as top companies have moved to update their purpose to focus on broader community concerns, rather than solely on shareholders.

Susan Lloyd-Hurwitz says property companies have a social responsibility. Peter Braig

The issue came to a head after Morton, seemingly with the imprimatur of the Prime Minister, said corporate Australia would do well to focus on profits, shareholders and their customers over social activism.

On a recent panel, property veteran Bruce Harper suggested that jumping on the social bandwagon can result in disingenuity. “AGL campaigns with the bearded work guy standing in front of windmills ... effectively saying we’re going to be out of coal,” Harper says. “Yet you look at their business plan and they’re going to rely for 80 per cent of their revenue for the next 20 or 30 years on fossil fuels, so a lot of that stuff becomes unbelievable.”

Business backlash

There has been a backlash in the US. Columbia Law School Professor Katharina Pistor asks: “Who are CEOs to autonomously change the rules of capitalism? Apparently, America’s corporate leaders believe they can decide freely whom they serve. But as agents, rather than principals, that decision really isn’t theirs to make.”

Questions about the merit of companies taking up social causes is an extension of a debate over directors’ duties. By law, directors are required to act in the best interests of the company. Some directors take “the company” to mean shareholders alone, but others argue the definition is broader and takes in customers and other stakeholders.

Former NAB chairman Ken Henry and others have suggested that directors’ duties should be changed to explicitly include the need to act in the interests of the whole “community”, rather than just shareholders.

The Australian Institute of Company Directors started a fresh debate about the law in March, but appeared to back away after members soon made it clear there was no case to change the law.

Lindsay Maxsted, chairman of Westpac and roads operator Transurban, insists that shareholder primacy still reigns supreme: “The customers haven’t appointed me, the community hasn’t appointed me, the shareholders have, so they own the company and have selected a group of people to act.”

Professor of corporate law at Melbourne University Ian Ramsay says part of the tension arises because the law has not dispelled the principle of shareholder primacy. He points to the 2011 decision of Justice Julie Ward, which maintains the duty to act in the best interests of the company “is generally interpreted to mean the shareholders as a whole ... often referred to as the shareholder primacy norm”.

Advertisement

Ramsay says he has always understood the duty of directors to provide scope to consider interests other than those of shareholders, but acknowledges the issue is “fiercely contested”, with a broad spectrum of views.

Charter Hall director Greg Paramor acknowledges part of the challenge is that social pursuits can often be hard to measure. “When you spend money on particular things, be it water or power, you can measure that,” he says. Socially minded campaigns prompt questions like: “Why did you spend two hours on that project which was about homeless people when you could have been out signing up a new lease?”

However, Paramor says companies also need to be guided by their shareholders, and more of them are asking: “What are you doing about the social side of your business?”

He says taking a stand on social and environmental issues can actually increase productivity. “I think you can interact the social things very much with your commercial outcomes and actually get a better result, because if you’ve got a happy workforce, you’re going to make more money and the shareholders are going to be better off,” he says.

Ramsay believes it would be a “disservice to public debate” to deny business leaders a voice. But he acknowledges that under the intense scrutiny of Canberra and tension within the business community, corporate leaders will need to be more diligent in making out a business case to back up their views.
description: Corporate Australia remains torn between its duty to shareholders and speaking up on environmental and social issues.
